You lost 5000 dollars.  You knew that 1 : 100 = 0,01 (or 1 : 0.01 = 100) And 451 x 100 = 451 : 0.01  Now lets try the math below with significant figures. 0.01 --> 2 sig figs 100 --> 1 sig fig. 451 --> 3 sig figs Right?  Now,  451 x 100 = ? 451 : 0,01 = ?  You will find  $ 451 x 100 = 50000 $ 451 : 0,01 = 45000  You lost 5000 dollars now THAT is significant LOL

The example of Pi vs 3.14 is backwards. 3.14 is an abbreviated and inaccurate approximation of Pi rounded to 2 significant digits. Pi the symbol represents Pi in its entirety, and is the most accurate way to use Pi.

Just wanted to add a fact for all JEE aspirants, in India while rounding of the digits when 5 is concerned, we have to check if the last digit is even or odd. Like , 1.65 will be rounded off to 1.6 while 1.75 goes to 1.8 (Concept of Physics 1, HC Verma, Page 22 Example 2.10)

Rules::: 1. All none zero digits are significant 2. All zero's between none zero digits are significant 3. All zero's before the first none zero are not significant 4. All zero's to the right of the last none zero digit are significant

Sorry, but when you put a (.) after the number and no number after the (.) I immediate assume there's a zero after it for example 13. to me is 13.0 and that would have 3 sig figs. It would be less ambiguous if you use whole numbers such as 13 without adding the (.) at the end. Just a suggestion :))

Sir how many types of significant are there ?
Zeros placed after the dot and before the first non-zero digit are not significant if the number is smaller than 1. So, just '80' in '0080' is significant.

Trailing zeros in a whole number with the decimal shown ARE significant. Placing a decimal at the end of a number is usually not done. By convention, however, this decimal indicates a significant zero. For example, "540." indicates that the trailing zero IS significant; there are THREE significant figures in this value.
They’re the same

As a chemistry teacher, since we were doing addition (or if subtraction), which is essentially based on decimal places, you wanted to round it to a whole number (23, so there's no decimal places); not to the tens place (not round further to 20). Counting the number of sigfigs of the entire answer is what you do when your math was multiplying or dividing.

@jasonbalne5651   Thank you for taking the time to reply. I was treating the 20 as a different case. I wanted to compare but maybe thats confusing. Instead I will give an example.  19 + 0.99 = 19.99 Now, if I round the answer according to the sigfigs of the terms, I round to the units place and note what the next digit to the right is. It is greater than five so I round by incrementing the units place by one. The rounded answer is 20. My question is "is the zero in the result of 20 a sigfig"? But now it seems to me it is obviously a sigfig. Thanks again.

If the math processes in the whole problem use the same rule (addition/subtraction or multiplication/division), then you can do the entire problem at once and round your final answer as appropriate. If the problem mixes rules, then you you have to do the like they are separate problems do the multiplication/division parts first using that rule. The example you show is all multiplication/division, so solve the whole thing and round to 1 sigfig (because the number 2 in the problem is 1 sigfig).
